summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2019 between defense attorney Michael Bachner and Assistant U.S. Attorneys from the Southern District of New York, primarily scheduling a 'reverse proffer' meeting regarding the Epstein investigation. It reveals legal strategy discussions, including a client's intent to invoke the Fifth Amendment before a grand jury.

persons.name: Michael Bachner
persons.context: Attorney communicating with federal prosecutors regarding scheduling a reverse proffer meeting and notifying them that his client will invoke the Fifth Amendment before the grand jury.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Federal prosecutor from the Southern District of New York corresponding with defense attorney Michael Bachner to schedule a meeting and discuss the grand jury process.

connections.description: Attorney for a client in the Epstein investigation communicating with a federal prosecutor regarding scheduling and legal strategy, including Fifth Amendment invocation.

events.title: Scheduled Reverse Proffer Meeting
events.description: A reverse proffer meeting was scheduled between defense attorney Michael Bachner and federal prosecutors from the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Fifth Amendment Invocation Notice
events.description: Michael Bachner notified federal prosecutors that his client would invoke her Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination if called to testify before the grand jury.

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: A reverse proffer meeting was being scheduled between defense attorney Michael Bachner and federal prosecutors in July 2019 regarding the Epstein investigation.
Michael Bachner notified prosecutors that his client would invoke the Fifth Amendment if called to testify before the grand jury.
The email chain references a client being arrested and arraigned in Queens County on a state RICO charge around July 15-16, 2019.
Prosecutors provided defense counsel with a copy of Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement and a blank proffer agreement.
